QuoteText: Reading over this thread, I stumbled upon this side-note of yours about Genesis being a pirated belief. Could you elaborate? I would be quite curious about any cultural origins of the Genesis story. Thanks.
ResponseText: Sorry, didn't notice that post. Anyways, Genesis as told in literal form follows the exact same steps of creation and of the flood as Enuma Elish and Gilgamesh. It's a accepted fact that Enuma Elish was ripped off from Gilgamesh. Given that all of the stories have the exact same steps, on the same timeline in the same region would seem to indicate that they are related, if not copies of each other. Gilgamesh's flood story differs in that it is polytheistic and that the Gods flooded the Earth because man was too loud, not evil.

ResponseText: The Epic of Gilgamesh and its story of Utnapishtim does indeed parallel the Noah story of the Bible very closely - in a way that is certainly not a coincidence. Looking up Enuma Elish, I don't see nearly as close a correspondence. I am mostly looking at the link: http://www.meta-religion.com/World_R...h_creation.htm and Wikipedia. Anyway, the parallel between the two stories mostly seems to be in the ordering of the stages of creation - six stages followed by rest. Though certain stages and certain orders would have to exist for any creation myth that subdivided creation in to sections, the fact that it was six and not five or ten or three stages does suggest some cultural communication. Such a connection is especially easy to believe since I understand that Abraham started off in Mesopotamia where he and his people certainly would have had access to these stories. I have always found it fascinating to discover the origins of beliefs and customs and to try to understand the context in which certain customs and beliefs arose. Where Christianity is concerned, the range of early Christian beliefs is amazing - far, far wider than exists today. So much of Christian belief has been shaped by the history and politics of ancient times. It is a fascinating puzzle to try to unravel.
